awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Barriers to Institutional Success in STEM at Central Michigan University
awd_abstract_narration:
Central Michigan University (CMU) will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to undertake faculty climate campus survey, focus group interviews with STEM faculty at CMU, interviews with STEM faculty who left CMU and candidates who turned down employment offers.  The project will include document and institutional data analyses to understand the barriers to success for STEM women faculty at CMU. Furthermore, the project will analyze how these barriers are similar or different depending on the academic department, race/ethnicity, and/or world region of origin. The project team will visit other ADVANCE institutions to learn about their success and struggles with similar issues and will invite expert speakers to come to CMU. They will host a pilot implicit bias training program for faculty in STEM departments and learn more about implicit bias and how it plays out in the CMU workplace to inform the development of the faculty equity strategic plan. This two-year project will prepare the university for future data collection and data analyses of faculty equity which can be used by institutional leadership to inform decision-making.  The Catalyst work will also prepare the institution to implement evidence-based strategies to enhance the university climate for all faculty which will be outlined in a five-year faculty equity strategic plan that will be produced as part of this project.   

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Central Michigan University (CMU) was awarded an NSF ADVANCE Catalyst grant in September 2019 entitled "Understanding the Barriers to Institutional Success for Women in STEM at Central Michigan University". Based on prior conversations with women faculty, the project explored the impact of implicit bias on gender equity. Our goals were to identify barriers to success for women STEM faculty, with multiple indicators of success including tenure and promotion, salary, leadership opportunities, and satisfaction. Our data collection included faculty focus group interviews and individual interviews as well as an analysis of institutional data (time to tenure and promotion, salary). We also analyzed bylaws of the fourteen STEM departments at CMU for potential bias. Finally, we provided training for faculty on ways to recognize and address implicit bias.

Faculty data collection and findings: We conducted 13 focus group interviews with faculty in the STEM disciplines and nine one-on-one interviews with faculty. Sixty-two of the 235 faculty members invited participated in the process. Our focus group interviews focused on four overarching categories: 1) recruitment and the reappointment, promotion, and tenure process, 2) workload, 3) mentoring, and 4) collegiality and bias. Women STEM faculty at CMU face both interpersonal and structural barriers to their work at CMU and are astutely aware of the lack of resources available to them in addressing such concerns. Women face more barriers while negotiating start-up funds and navigating the RPT process. Women recognize and are frustrated with unequal workloads between men and women faculty, especially in regards to service. Women also experience a less collegial environment at CMU. Additional interviews and focus groups included: individuals that declined a faculty position offer, individuals that had recently left a CMU STEM faculty position, and STEM department chairs. Women earn tenure approximately six months later than men, had lower starting salaries, and published less than men. We also found that committee composition at the university level can be very gender biased, with men more often serving on research-focused committees and women more often serving on teaching-focused committees.

Bylaws analyses and findings: We analyzed the bylaws of our 14 STEM departments for transparency, clarity of standards, flexibility of work-life awareness, accountability, and consistency with a focus on the following areas: reappointment, promotion, and tenure, departmental policies and procedures, department chairs, other leadership positions, and departmental committees. Almost all departmental bylaws contain vague or inconsistent language regarding the tenure and promotion process. Generally, there is a lack of transparency and clarity in the bylaws regarding policies and procedures around departmental issues including bylaws changes, faculty recruitment, scheduling of meetings, allocation of space and funds, and teaching assignments.

Implicit bias trainings: We took two approaches to implicit bias training: 1) virtual book club discussions for faculty from STEM departments as well as for department chairs and college leadership in the College of Science and Engineering, and 2) two interactive virtual workshops about bystander reactions to social biases and how these reactions can help or hinder decisions to speak up for all CMU faculty. We also hosted two speakers for campus wide presentations on gender equity issues.

Recommendations: We identified several barriers for women STEM faculty at Central Michigan University, including issues with departmental climate, ambiguity in tenure and promotion processes, and service expectations. We recommend:

-       Changing the campus culture with additional trainings to identify and interrupt bias, further equity practices by those in leadership roles, and support equality for faculty, department chairs, and administration,

-       Developing equitable and transparent policies by revising department laws, increasing access and transparency to faculty-equity data, and reviewing university policies and procedures, and

-       Creating more inclusive recruitment and mentoring practices by providing resources for potential and current faculty and establishing mentoring opportunities to build support and access to leadership opportunities.

 As a result of this project, we have created awareness and ongoing conversation about gender and other forms of bias at our institution. Furthermore, as part of a regular administrative review cycle of department bylaws, the College of Science and Engineering has recommended changes to departments regarding their bylaws with the intent to increase equity and transparency within the bylaws.
